items.label: thm-qsd-exchangeability
items.title: Exchangeability of the QSD
items.content:
14: :label: thm-qsd-exchangeability
15: 
16: Let $\pi_N \in \mathcal{P}(\Sigma_N)$ be the unique Quasi-Stationary Distribution of the Euclidean Gas. Then $\pi_N$ is an **exchangeable probability measure**: for any permutation $\sigma \in S_N$ and any measurable set $A \subseteq \Sigma_N$:
17: 
18: $$
19: \pi_N(\{(w_1, \ldots, w_N) \in A\}) = \pi_N(\{(w_{\sigma(1)}, \ldots, w_{\sigma(N)}) \in A\})
20: $$

items.label: thm-hewitt-savage-representation
items.title: Finite de Finetti Representation
items.content:
53: :label: thm-hewitt-savage-representation
54: 
55: Since $\pi_N$ is exchangeable on the compact space $\Omega$, there exists a probability measure $\mathcal{Q}_N$ on $\mathcal{P}(\Omega)$ (the **mixing measure**) such that for any $k$-particle marginal with $1 \leq k \leq N$:
56: 
57: $$
58: d_{\text{TV}}\left(\pi_{N,k}, \int_{\mathcal{P}(\Omega)} \mu^{\otimes k} \, d\mathcal{Q}_N(\mu)\right) \leq \frac{k(k-1)}{2N}
59: $$
60: 
61: where $\pi_{N,k}$ is the law of the first $k$ walkers under $\pi_N$, $\mu^{\otimes k}$ denotes the $k$-fold product measure (walkers are i.i.d. with law $\mu$), and $d_{\text{TV}}$ is total variation distance.
62: 
63: **Key consequences**:
64: 
65: 1. **Low-order marginals** ($k$ fixed, $N \to \infty$): The bound is $O(1/N)$
66:    - Pairwise marginals ($k=2$): $d_{\text{TV}} \leq 1/N$
67:    - Single-particle marginal ($k=1$): exact representation
68: 
69: 2. **Full N-particle distribution** ($k=N$): The bound is $O(N)$
70:    - $d_{\text{TV}}(\pi_N, \int \mu^{\otimes N} d\mathcal{Q}_N) \leq (N-1)/2$
71:    - Representation becomes exact only in the limit $N \to \infty$
72: 
73: **Interpretation**: The QSD can be **approximately** represented as a mixture of IID configurations. The approximation is excellent for low-order marginals ($k \ll N$), which is precisely what is needed for correlation decay and propagation of chaos.
74: 
75: **Construction**: The mixing measure $\mathcal{Q}_N$ is the law of the empirical measure $L_N = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \delta_{w_i}$ when $(w_1, \ldots, w_N) \sim \pi_N$.

items.label: thm-propagation-chaos-qsd
items.title: Propagation of Chaos
items.content:
220: :label: thm-propagation-chaos-qsd
221: 
222: As $N \to \infty$, the single-particle marginal $\mu_N$ converges weakly to a unique limit $\mu_\infty \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)$:
223: 
224: $$
225: \mu_N \Rightarrow \mu_\infty
226: $$
227: 
228: Moreover, $\mu_\infty$ is the unique stationary solution of the mean-field McKean-Vlasov equation:
229: 
230: $$
231: \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t} = \mathcal{L}[\rho] \rho
232: $$

items.label: thm-correlation-decay
items.title: Quantitative Decorrelation
items.content:
280: :label: thm-correlation-decay
281: 
282: For bounded single-particle test functions $g: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ with $\|g\|_{\infty} \leq 1$:
283: 
284: $$
285: \left|\text{Cov}_{\pi_N}(g(w_i), g(w_j))\right| \leq \frac{C}{N}
286: $$
287: 
288: for $i \neq j$, where $C$ is independent of $N$.

items.label: thm-mixing-variance-corrected
items.title: Variance of Mixing Measure
items.content:
380: :label: thm-mixing-variance-corrected
381: 
382: Let $\pi_N = \int \mu^{\otimes N} d\mathcal{Q}_N(\mu)$ be the de Finetti representation of the QSD, and let $\rho_0$ be the mean-field limit. Assume the quantitative KL bound from {prf:ref}`lem-quantitative-kl-bound` (document `12_quantitative_error_bounds.md`):
383: 
384: $$
385: D_{KL}(\pi_N \| \rho_0^{\otimes N}) \leq \frac{C_{\text{int}}}{N}
386: $$
387: 
388: Then for any bounded measurable function $g: \Omega \to \mathbb{R}$ with $\|g\|_{\infty} \leq B$:
389: 
390: $$
391: \text{Var}_{\mathcal{Q}_N}(\mathbb{E}_{\mu}[g]) \leq \frac{2 \cdot e^{C_{\text{int}}/N} \cdot B^2}{N}
392: $$
393: 
394: For sufficiently large $N$ (such that $e^{C_{\text{int}}/N} \leq 3/2$):
395: 
396: $$
397: \text{Var}_{\mathcal{Q}_N}(\mathbb{E}_{\mu}[g]) \leq \frac{3B^2}{N}
398: $$
399: 
400: **Consequence**: Combined with the corrected de Finetti identity:
401: 
402: $$
403: |\text{Cov}_{\pi_N}(g(w_i), g(w_j))| = \text{Var}_{\mathcal{Q}_N}(\mathbb{E}_{\mu}[g]) \leq \frac{3\|g\|_{\infty}^2}{N}
404: $$
